item.title: Arc Raiders has an impressive 2025 roadmap, and it's bringing a new map, new events, and other game-changers
item.content:encoded:
Arc Raiders now has an official roadmap for the rest of 2025, and considering there's only two months left in the year, it's slammed full of a substantial amount of new experiences for players to try out.

Initially posted by the Arc Raiders social media accounts, the Arc Raiders roadmap reveals that in November's 'North Line' update, we'll gain access to a new map: Stella Montis. There'll also be two new Arc enemies, a community-unlock event, as well as new quests and items.

As for December, the ‘Cold Snap’ update will bring the new snowfall map condition, the ‘Flickering Flames’ event, more new quests, a new raider deck for players to progress through, as well as the game's first departure window (or, in common parlance, an optional character reset).

Now, some of these additions remain largely mysterious, we don't know what the community-unlock event actually entails as of writing, but even with these gaps in knowledge that's at least one major thing added to the game each month. That is, it's safe to say, a huge amount of new content coming to Arc Raiders so soon after release.

It's a similar cadence to what Embark Studios brought to The Finals, which had some manner of in-game event or other twist on the formula every few weeks or so. Whether it can keep the strong momentum going for Arc Raiders remains to be seen, but given it's performing exceptionally well for an extraction shooter so far, things are certainly looking up for the game.

If you've not jumped in yet, why not read Eurogamer's preview of the game, which opens with the following: "There's a rare experience with video games when an entire genre just clicks for you. A moment when the appeal makes sense. Crawling onto an elevator with a backpack full of loot, hastily initiating the extraction sequence with seconds left to live, Arc Raiders did exactly that. It let off a firework in my head. How was I ever not a fan of this?"

item.title: The Witcher author Andrzej Sapkowski says it's "rare" for CD Projekt Red to ask for additional details now
item.content:encoded:
"The contracts between me and the game people are excellent right now. Let's hope it stays that way."

The Witcher author Andrzej Sapkowski says he has an "excellent" deal with developer CD Projekt Red, but admits it's "rare" that the studio gets in touch to ask for additional details these days.

Addressing fans at a book event to promote his Witcher prequel book, Crossroads of Ravens (thanks, GamesRadar+), Sapkowski revealed that while he had worked more closely with CDPR on prior games, he had not been approached to contribute to The Witcher 4, but insisted "the contracts between me and the game people are excellent right now".

"Let's hope it stays that way," he added.

Back in 2017, Sapkowski told Eurogamer the global success of The Witcher following the release of the third game in the series hadn't made him any money because he sold the rights to CD Projekt for a lump sum without asking for royalties, prompting a new deal in 2019.

"I was stupid enough to sell them rights to the whole bunch," Sapkowski told Eurogamer at the time. "They offered me a percentage of their profits. I said, 'No, there will be no profit at all - give me all my money right now! The whole amount.' It was stupid. I was stupid enough to leave everything in their hands because I didn't believe in their success. But who could foresee their success? I couldn't."

As for more recent The Witcher news? Last month, Sapkowski discussed a key plot point in the video game series that was actually a mistake in his novels, saying "video game people have clung to the idea with remarkable tenacity".

"The issue of 'witcher schools' requires - I apologise - a longer explanation," Sapkowski told a questioner in an AMA. "A single sentence about some 'school of the Wolf' mysteriously made its way into The Last Wish. I later deemed it unworthy of development and narratively incorrect, even detrimental to the plot. Therefore, later I never included or referenced any Witcher Gryffindors or Slytherins again. Never.

"However, that one sentence was enough. Adaptors, particularly video game people, have clung to the idea with remarkable tenacity and have wonderfully multiplied these 'witcher schools'. Completely unnecessary."
